leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 75] s 75 Settlement of claim made on behalf of, or against, person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Settlement of claim made on behalf of, or against, person under legal incapacity (cf SCR Part 63, rule 13)

p.text: This section applies to any claim, enforceable by proceedings in the court, that is made by or on behalf of, or against, a person under legal incapacity.

If, before proceedings are commenced with respect to any such claim, an agreement for the compromise or settlement of the claim is made by or on behalf of the person under legal incapacity, the court may approve or disapprove the agreement.
An agreement disapproved by the court does not bind the person under legal incapacity.

An agreement approved by the court binds the person under legal incapacity as if he or she were of full capacity and (if it was made by some other person on his or her behalf) as if that other person had made the agreement as his or her agent.

The present section contemplates that agreements for the compromise or settlement of claims by or on behalf of a “person under legal incapacity” may be made before any proceedings have been commenced. The ultimate efficacy of any such agreement, in binding the “person under incapacity” depends on obtaining subsequent court approval. The extent to which any such agreement operates to impose any obligations on the parties to seek court approval, and precluding them from relying on events that occur after the purported agreement, is discussed in [s 76.25] .

The court has protective function in relation to the approval of compromises involving persons under legal incapacity. Before approving a compromise involving such a person the court must be satisfied that the terms of settlement are proper (ie, reasonable and in the best interests of the incapable person): Yu Ge v River Island Clothing Pty Ltd (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-638; [2002] NSWSC 28; BC200200140 (O'Keefe J); Overall v Terpu [2003] NSWSC 986; BC200306537 . That assessment will necessarily involve some consideration of the potentially recoverable damages, but the court is not required to assess the amount of damages that might be awarded on the (hypothetical) trial of the proceedings: see McWilliams v McWilliams (1967) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 6 .

The reasonableness of the compromise should be attested to by the incapable person’s tutor and supported by counsel’s advice: Re Birchall (1880) 16 Ch D 41 . The court is not bound to accede to the views expressed in that supporting evidence and ought to assess itself the reasonableness of the compromise. But in the ordinary case the court will attach significance to the considered views of the tutor and the incapable person’s legal advisers: Yu Ge v River Island Clothing Pty Ltd (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-638; [2002] NSWSC 28; BC200200140 (O'Keefe J). The court cannot force upon an incapable person a compromise that is contrary to the opinion of person’s tutor and legal advisers: Re Ley's Trusts [1964] 1 WLR 640 .

Where a judge declines to approve a settlement the judge should not proceed to hear the action: Re Hornby; Ex parte Prentice [1970] 1 NSWR 654; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 427 ; Yu Ge v River Island Clothing Pty Ltd, above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 76] s 76 Settlement of proceedings commenced by or on behalf of, or against, person under legal incapacity (cf Act No 25 1929, section 4)

leg:heading.title: Settlement of proceedings commenced by or on behalf of, or against, person under legal incapacity (cf Act No 25 1929, section 4)

p.text: This section applies to proceedings commenced by or on behalf of, or against, any of the following persons:
a person under legal incapacity,
a person who, during the course of the proceedings, becomes a person under legal incapacity,
a person whom the court finds, during the course of the proceedings, to be incapable of managing his or her own affairs.
[subs (1) am Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2[3], effective 14 December 2007]

The court may make a finding referred to in subsection (1)(c) only on the basis of evidence given in the proceedings in which it is made, and such a finding has effect for the purpose only of those proceedings.
Except with the approval of the court, there may not be:
any compromise or settlement of any proceedings to which this section applies, or
any acceptance of money paid into court in any such proceedings,
as regards a claim made by or on behalf of, or against, a person referred to in subsection (1).
[subs (3) am Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2[4], effective 14 December 2007]

If an agreement for the compromise or settlement of any matter in dispute in any such proceedings is made by or on behalf of a person referred to in subsection (1), the court may approve or disapprove the agreement.
An agreement disapproved by the court does not bind the person by whom or on whose behalf it was made.

An agreement approved by the court binds the person by whom or on whose behalf it was made as if he or she were of full capacity and (if it was made by some other person on his or her behalf) as if that other person had made the agreement as his or her agent.
Legislation cited in [s 76.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3, ss 75, 76.
(NSW) Damages (Infants and Persons of Unsound Mind) Act 1929.

The section applies to all proceedings by or against a “person under legal incapacity”, irrespective of whether that incapacity applies because of the definition in CPA s 3 or from disability definitions in other legislation: Laurenson v Plain [1974] 2 NSWLR 312 . It applies whatever the nature of the claim, and is not restricted to claims for monetary damages (as was the case with the Damages (Infants and Persons of Unsound Mind) Act 1929 ).

CPA ss 75 and 76 provide a procedure for obtaining approval of a settlement. They are facultative, rather than prescriptive, and do not restrict the court’s power to give or withhold approval: Permanent Trustee Co Ltd v Mills (2007) 71 NSWLR 1; [2007] NSWSC 336; BC200702716 at [8]–[28] per Hammerschlag J (the court used its inherent jurisdiction to approve a settlement of proceedings where a previous version of s 76 did not apply to proceedings against a person under incapacity).

The court’s function on an application for approval is essentially protective. The court ought to scrutinize the terms of the settlement or compromise to protect the interests of the person under legal incapacity: Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170 at 189; [1967] 2 All ER 282; [1967] 3 WLR 165 per Lord Pearson. The proper discharge of this function essentially requires the court to determine whether it is satisfied that the settlement or compromise is beneficial to the interests of the person under legal incapacity: Re Ley's Will Trusts [1964] 2 All ER 326; [1964] 1 WLR 640 at 643 ; Permanent Trustee Co Ltd v Mills (2007) 71 NSWLR 1; [2007] NSWSC 336; BC200702716 at [29] per Hammerschlag J; Fairhurst (bht NSW Trustee and Guardian) v Fairhurst [2012] NSWSC 388; BC201202770 at [37], [38] . Unless the court is affirmatively satisfied that the settlement or compromise is for the person’s benefit it should withhold approval, and the person concerned will not be bound: Rhodes v Swithenbank (1889) 22 QBD 577 at 578–9 .

The question of benefit will typically turn on an assessment whether there is sufficient prospect of obtaining a more favourable judgment, to outweigh the value of the certainty reflected in the settlement or compromise: Elderfield v Transport Accident Commission (2010) 55 MVR 206; [2010] VSC 116; BC201002060 ; Karvelas v Chikirow (1976) 11 ACTR 22; 26 FLR 381 ; Elliott v Diener (1978) 21 ACTR 21 . For example, a settlement involving the dismissal or withdrawal of arguable proceedings, without any substantial benefit to the incapable person, is unlikely to be approved as being in their best interests: Porter v Phong Le [2010] NSWSC 998; BC201006588 at [7]–[11] (tutor proposed settlement principally to avoid costs risk).

Fairhurst (bht NSW Trustee and Guardian) v Fairhurst [2012] NSWSC 388; BC201202770 at [37], [38] (settlement opposed by non-party sibling — no offer of indemnity for the costs of the proceedings — settlement approved);

Institoris by his next friend Maria Institoris v Falconer [2012] NSWCA 298; BC201207366 (young child — well resolved fracture injury — claim for future economic loss — modest settlement — approved as reasonable taking into account the litigation risk).

Fisher (by her tutor) Fisher v Marin [2008] NSWSC 1357; BC200811207 at [29], [41] (birth defect claim — accepted offer involving substantial discount — change of legal adviser — settlement approval opposed by plaintiff — apparently strong basis for claim — settlement disapproved).

(NSW) Damages (Infants and Persons of Unsound Mind) Act 1929 s 4.

heading.title: Compromise of issues or interim payments

p.text: CPA s 76(4) extends to the compromise or settlement of "any matter in dispute" in the proceedings. It includes compromise on issues of liability, as well as damages Davis v Mid North Coast Area Health Service [2007] NSWSC 1044; BC200708027 (where there is a compromise on a separate issue of liability, confidentiality directions can be made restricting disclosure of the agreed percentage discount on the ultimate damages assessment). The section also gives the court power to sanction an agreement concerning interim payments to a plaintiff in respect of particular heads of damage: Drake v Bodycott [1982] 2 NSWLR 496 (contrasting, s 4 of the Damages (Infants and Persons of Unsound Mind) Act 1929 ).

level.toc-caption: [s 76.20] Practice and procedure relating to approval of settlements

heading.title: Practice and procedure relating to approval of settlements

p.text: The terms and effect of the settlement should be clearly set out in the material put to the court. This should include a statement of the net settlement amount after allowance for all costs and disbursements: see eg the specific requirement in the District Court — Practice Note DC (Civil) 7 Court approved settlements.

The proposed compromise should be assented to by the person’s tutor and supported by their legal advisers opinion that they consider the proposed settlement to be in the person’s best interests: Re Birchall (1880) 16 Ch D 41 at 43 .

In discharging its approval function the court will ordinarily attach significant weight to the opinions of the person’s legal advisers: Stephens-Sidebottom v Victoria (Department of Education and Early Childhod Development) [2011] FCA 893; BC201105822 at [12] . That is especially the case if they oppose approval of the settlement: Re Birchall (1880) 16 Ch D 41 ; Fisher v Marin [2008] NSWSC 1357; BC200811207 at [33] (plaintiff’s offer of compromise — new legal advisers opposed approval of defendant’s acceptance). The court will, in any event, have regard to any substantial grounds of opposition to the settlement: Darwalla Milling Co Pty Ltd v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd (No 2) (2006) 236 ALR 322; (2007) ATPR 42-134; [2006] FCA 1388; BC200608652 at [39] .

If the court considers that the proposed compromise has been unreasonably or improperly either promoted or re-sisted by the guardian or tutor, the appropriate course is to take steps to remove the guardian or tutor, and have a new person appointed: arrangement against their dissent: Re Birchall, above at 42 per Jessel MR; Porter v Phong Le [2010] NSWSC 998; BC201006588 at [5] .

(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3, ss 75(3), (4), s 76(3), 76(4), (5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 20.27.

The true nature of an agreement for compromise or settlement involving claims by or against persons under legal incapacity depends on the circumstances of the communications between the parties and the statutory provisions governing the court’s approval function: Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170; [1967] 2 All ER 282; [1967] 3 WLR 165 . Where a settlement is expressly, or necessarily, “subject to the approval of the court”, the relevant statutory provisions may indicate no agreement is valid, and cannot be regarded as having been “made”, before the court grants approval: Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170 at 182–3, 190; [1967] 2 All ER 282; [1967] 3 WLR 165 ; Drinkall v Whitwood [2003] All ER (D) 76 (Nov); [2004] 4 All ER 378; [2004] 1 WLR 462; [2003] EWCA Civ 1547 at [19] (party entitled to resile from proposed agreement). However, the CPA provisions appear to contemplate that an agreement for compromise or settlement may be “made” before any court approval (at least in those situations where the “person under incapacity” (within the meaning of CPA s 3 ) does not lack ordinary contractual capacity): Azar v Kathirgamalingan [2012] NSWCA 429; BC201210040 at [184] . Under these provisions the court approval, or disapproval, determines whether the agreement ultimately binds the person under legal incapacity. The initial absence of court approval does not preclude a finding that a settlement agreement has been “made”: CPA ss 75(3) and (4) and 76(4) and (5) ; but compare CPA s 76(3) .

Where the parties have in fact “made” an agreement, but it is subject to court approval, the obligation to seek approval is implicit in the nature of the proposed agreement: Mitchell v Osborne (NSWSC, Young J, 20 May 1997, unreported, BC9702446). There is a similar obligation where the tutor of a person under legal incapacity has accepted a formal offer of compromise under UCPR 20.27 : Azar v Kathirgamalingan [2012] NSWCA 429; BC201210040 at [198] , [199]. Either party may seek court approval. Neither party can unilaterally resile from the agreement: Smallman v Smallman [1972] Fam 25 at 31G; [1971] 3 All ER 717; [1971] 3 WLR 588 (divorce proceedings — settlement agreed subject to formal orders — husband could not resile from agreement terms).

Where a proposed settlement or compromise is regarded as immediately binding, and the parties bound to seek court approval, the obligation is nevertheless one that requires candour in relation to all relevant considerations: Smallman v Smallman [1972] Fam 25 at 31E; [1971] 3 All ER 717; [1971] 3 WLR 588 . The court retains the power to withhold approval — either because of changed underlying circumstances: Affoo v Public Trustee of Queensland [2012] 1 Qd R 408; [2011] QSC 309; BC201108181 (elderly applicant for family provision — death prior to approval — settlement not approved); Groser v Equity Trustees Ltd (2008) 19 VR 598; [2008] VSC 163; BC200803436 (similar case); or because of changed advice to the parties: Fisher v Marin [2008] NSWSC 1357; BC200811207 at [33] (plaintiff’s offer of compromise — new legal advisers opposed approval of defendant’s acceptance).

Where the settlement is only intended to have effect upon approval by the court, and formal approval is required both as a matter of substantive law (with respect to persons who lack contractual capacity) and as a precondition of the settlement terms coming into effect, the form of the approval is usually in terms that “the settlement of these proceedings be and is hereby approved”: Permanent Trustee Co Ltd v Mills (2007) 71 NSWLR 1; [2007] NSWSC 336; BC200702716 at [49]–[50] (citing Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170; [1967] 2 All ER 282; [1967] 3 WLR 165 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 77] s 77 Payment of money recovered on behalf of person under legal incapacity (cf Act No 25 1929, section 4)

leg:heading.title: Payment of money recovered on behalf of person under legal incapacity (cf Act No 25 1929, section 4)

p.text: This section applies to money recovered in any proceedings on behalf of any of the following persons:
a person under legal incapacity,
a person who, during the course of the proceedings, becomes a person under legal incapacity,
a person whom the court has found, under section 76(1)(c) , to be incapable of managing his or her own affairs,
pursuant to a compromise, settlement, judgment or order in any proceedings.
All money recovered on behalf of a person referred to in subsection (1) is to be paid into court.
Despite subsection (2), the court may order that the whole or any part of such money not be paid into court but be paid instead to such person as the court may direct, including:
if the person is a minor, to the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or
if the person is a protected person, to the manager of the protected person’s estate.
[subs (3) subst Act 56 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 20 June 2006 ; am Act 49 of 2009 Sch 2.9[3], effective 1 July 2009]
Money paid into court under subsection (2) is to be paid to such person as the court may direct, including:
if the person is a minor, to the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or
if the person is a protected person, to the manager of the protected person’s estate.
[subs (4) subst Act 56 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 20 June 2006 ; am Act 49 of 2009 Sch 2.9[3], effective 1 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [s 77.5] Order for payment to the NSW Trustee (previously the Public Trustee)

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 77.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 77(2).

heading.title: Order for payment to the NSW Trustee (previously the Public Trustee)

p.text: It is undesirable for a court to order payment to the NSW Trustee (previously the Public Trustee) in the absence of evidence of the NSW Trustee’s willingness to act as trustee of the judgment monies. In the absence of evidence of the NSW Trustee’s consent, the judgment monies should be paid into court in accordance with CPA s 77(2) . When evidence of the NSW Trustee’s consent is available the court may order the monies in court to be paid out to the NSW Trustee: Russell v Rail Infrastructure Corp [2007] NSWSC 447; BC200703413 at [12] (plaintiff found to be a person incapable of managing her own affairs, requested (by tutor) that the Public Trustee hold verdict monies in trust).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 78] s 78 Application of money by NSW Trustee and Guardian (cf Act No 25 1929, section 5(1), (2) and (3))

leg:heading.title: Application of money by NSW Trustee and Guardian (cf Act No 25 1929, section 5(1), (2) and (3))

p.text: Subject to any order of the court, money paid under this Division to the NSW Trustee and Guardian on behalf of a minor is to be held and applied by the NSW Trustee and Guardian for the maintenance and education of, or otherwise for the benefit of, the minor.
On the application of the NSW Trustee and Guardian, the Supreme Court may give directions to the NSW Trustee and Guardian as to the administration of any such money.
If given effect to by the NSW Trustee and Guardian, any such direction exonerates the NSW Trustee and Guardian from any claim or demand by any other person.
[s 78 am Act 49 of 2009 Sch 2.9[3], effective 1 July 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 79] s 79 Application of money by manager of protected person’s estate (cf Act No 25 1929, section 5(4))

leg:heading.title: Application of money by manager of protected person’s estate (cf Act No 25 1929, section 5(4))

p.text: Subject to any order of the court, money paid under this Division to the manager of a protected person’s estate is to be held and applied by the manager as part of that estate.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 80] s 80 Directions to tutor of person under legal incapacity

leg:heading.title: Directions to tutor of person under legal incapacity

p.text: On the application of the tutor for a person under legal incapacity, the Supreme Court may give directions with respect to the tutor’s conduct of proceedings, whether before the Supreme Court or any other court, on behalf of that person.
